member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.WriteableCollections.AbstractGeometryWriteableCollection.GetReadOnlyCopy
member.summary: Get a read-only copy of this collection, leaving this collection unaffected (still writeable).
member.remarks:
This method differs from ToReadOnly() in that it makes a copy of the collection, but leaves the collection in a writeable state.
Use ToReadOnly() for better performance when you don't need to work with the writeable collection afterward. Use GetReadOnlyCopy() when you want to allow modifying the writeable collection afterward.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.CoordinateSystems.Coordinate2D.Cross(Microsoft.MapPoint.CoordinateSystems.Coordinate2D)
member.summary: Calculates the cross product of two 2D coordinates.
member.param: The right hand side of the expression. The object "this" is the left handle side of the expression.
member.returns: The cross product of left and right. If the result is less than 0, then right is clockwise from left. If the result is greater than 0, right is counter-clockwise from left, and if the result equals 0, both coordinates have the same slope.

member.summary: Calculates the dot product of two 2D coordinates.
member.param: The right hand side of the expression. The object "this" is the left hand side of the expression
member.returns: The dot product of left and right.

member.summary: If the count of vertexes is greater than this number, the last two coordinates in the collection are in fact the bounding box coordinates.

member.summary: The increase in size that occurs when a bounding box is used.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.Coordinate2DCollection.CreateUnsafe(Microsoft.MapPoint.CoordinateSystems.Coordinate2D[])
member.summary: Create a lightweight wrapper around an existing array. NOTE: This is unsafe and places the burden of caution on the caller not to modify the array after passing it in.
member.remarks: This method creates a Coordinate2DTwoVerticesCollection or Coordinate2DMultipleVerticesCollection, as appropriate based on the number of vertices in the array passed in. This method is provided as a convenience to make the existence of those two subclass collection less obtrusive in the API. For the sake of performance, however, if a caller happens to have just two vertices, it's more performant to construct a Coordinate2DTwoVerticesCollection directly instead of creating an array of two vertices and then calling this method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.Coordinate2DCollection.GetMinMaxCoordinates(Microsoft.MapPoint.CoordinateSystems.Coordinate2D@,Microsoft.MapPoint.CoordinateSystems.Coordinate2D@)
member.summary: Returns the maximum and minimum X and Y values that appear in the collection.
member.param: The largest X and Y values that appear.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.WriteableCollections.Coordinate2DWriteableCollection.GetReadOnlyCopy
member.summary: Get a read-only copy of this collection, leaving this collection unaffected (still writeable).
member.remarks:
This method differs from ToReadOnly() in that it makes a copy of the collection, but leaves the collection in a writeable state.
Use ToReadOnly() for better performance when you don't need to work with the writeable collection afterward. Use GetReadOnlyCopy() when you want to allow modifying the writeable collection afterward.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.Coordinate2DFixedPointCollection.CreateUnsafe(Microsoft.MapPoint.CoordinateSystems.Coordinate2DFixedPoint[])
member.summary: Create a lightweight wrapper around an existing array. NOTE: This is unsafe and places the burden of caution on the caller not to modify the array after passing it in.
member.remarks: This method creates a Coordinate2DFixedPointTwoVerticesCollection or Coordinate2DFixedPointMultipleVerticesCollection, as appropriate based on the number of vertices in the array passed in. This method is provided as a convenience to make the existence of those two subclass collection less obtrusive in the API. For the sake of performance, however, if a caller happens to have just two vertices, it's more performant to construct a Coordinate2DFixedPointTwoVerticesCollection directly instead of creating an array of two vertices and then calling this method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.WriteableCollections.Coordinate2DFixedPointWriteableCollection.GetReadOnlyCopy
member.summary: Get a read-only copy of this collection, leaving this collection unaffected (still writeable).
member.remarks:
This method differs from ToReadOnly() in that it makes a copy of the collection, but leaves the collection in a writeable state.
Use ToReadOnly() for better performance when you don't need to work with the writeable collection afterward. Use GetReadOnlyCopy() when you want to allow modifying the writeable collection afterward.

member.summary: If the count of vertexes is greater than this number, the last two coordinates in the collection are in fact the bounding box coordinates.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.Coordinate3DCollection.CreateUnsafe(Microsoft.MapPoint.CoordinateSystems.Coordinate3D[])
member.summary: Create a lightweight wrapper around an existing array. NOTE: This is unsafe and places the burden of caution on the caller not to modify the array after passing it in.
member.remarks: This method creates a Coordinate3DTwoVerticesCollection or Coordinate3DMultipleVerticesCollection, as appropriate based on the number of vertices in the array passed in. This method is provided as a convenience to make the existence of those two subclass collection less obtrusive in the API. For the sake of performance, however, if a caller happens to have just two vertices, it's more performant to construct a Coordinate3DTwoVerticesCollection directly instead of creating an array of two vertices and then calling this method.

member.name: T:Microsoft.MapPoint.CoordinateSystems.IDatum
member.summary:
Datum interface transforms local spherical coordinates into global cartesian coordinates and vice versa.
A datum is a best fit spherical coordinate system that varies according to geopolitical entities.
WGS84 is the internationally accepted datum that best describes the entire surface of the earth.
An ellipsoid is a simpler approximation of the earth's shape that captures flattening at the poles.
A sphere is an even simpler approximation of the earth's shape that is uniformly round.
member.TODO: Returning values with outs is ugly. Eliminate out returns with function return of Vector3D or LLA as appropriate when these get defined.

member.param: Latitude in local coodinates

member.name: T:Microsoft.MapPoint.CoordinateSystems.Wgs84SpatialOperations
member.summary: Spatial operations for the WGS 84 Coordinate Reference System. The coordinate type is latlong represented in a Coordinate2D.

member.name: T:Microsoft.MapPoint.CoordinateSystems.SpatialOperations
member.summary:
SpatialOperations.
Many, if not most, spatial operations depend on the type of CRS. At a minimum, for instance, are lines interpolated linearly (engineering CRS) or geodesically (geographic CRS). Because of this, the geometry classes themselves can not implement most spatial operations. They must delegate this to the CRS.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.CoordinateSystems.SpatialOperations.GetVertexDistances(Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.Coordinate2DFixedPointCollection)
member.summary: Returns the pairwise vertex distance of all coordinates in the input geometry. For example, if a Polyline has 3 vertices A,B,C then an array with two elements is returned. The first value is for the distance A-B, the second value for the distance B-C. There will always be one less value than there are vertices. If a zero dimensional geometry is submitted (i.e. a point) the method will return a one element array with a value of 0.

If a zero dimensional geometry is submitted (i.e. a point) the method will return a one element array with a value of 0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.WriteableCollections.Ring2DWriteableCollection.GetReadOnlyCopy
member.summary: Get a read-only copy of this collection, leaving this collection unaffected (still writeable).
member.remarks:
This method differs from ToReadOnly() in that it makes a copy of the collection, but leaves the collection in a writeable state.
Use ToReadOnly() for better performance when you don't need to work with the writeable collection afterward. Use GetReadOnlyCopy() when you want to allow modifying the writeable collection afterward.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.WriteableCollections.Ring2WriteableCollection.GetReadOnlyCopy
member.summary: Get a read-only copy of this collection, leaving this collection unaffected (still writeable).
member.remarks:
This method differs from ToReadOnly() in that it makes a copy of the collection, but leaves the collection in a writeable state.
Use ToReadOnly() for better performance when you don't need to work with the writeable collection afterward. Use GetReadOnlyCopy() when you want to allow modifying the writeable collection afterward.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.WriteableCollections.Ring3WriteableCollection.GetReadOnlyCopy
member.summary: Get a read-only copy of this collection, leaving this collection unaffected (still writeable).
member.remarks:
This method differs from ToReadOnly() in that it makes a copy of the collection, but leaves the collection in a writeable state.
Use ToReadOnly() for better performance when you don't need to work with the writeable collection afterward. Use GetReadOnlyCopy() when you want to allow modifying the writeable collection afterward.

member.summary: Returns a string representation of this intersection.

member.summary: Gets the position in space at which the ray intersected the Tag.

member.summary: Gets the distance from the source to the point at which the intersection occurred.

member.summary: Gets the normal of the surface on which the ray intersected.

member.name: P:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Ray3DIntersection.FaceIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of the face that was hit.

member.name: P:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Ray3DIntersection.Source
member.summary: Gets or sets the object that initiated the intersection test that caused this intersection. Note that this value is copied from if this object is added to a list. The reason for this is that multiple things may perform intersection tests and their results get aggregated.

member.name: P:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Ray3DIntersection.Tag
member.summary: Gets a pointer to the object that was hit by this intersection. Note that this value can be changed as its intended usage is that methods higher up the call stack may create new objects with the old tag stored inside in order to communicate more information upward.

member.name: P:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Ray3DIntersection.Properties
member.summary: Provides properties about the type of intersections supported by the intersected object. May be null if the object did not supply them.

member.name: P:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Ray3DIntersection.Presort
member.summary: A comparable to use to sort intersections before accounting for distance. If null, distance will be used first instead.

member.name: P:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Ray3DIntersection.Postsort
member.summary: A comparable to use to sort intersections if the presort and distance are equal. If null, only the presort (if present) and distance will be used.

member.name: T:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Ray3DIntersectionInclude
member.summary: Specify additional tests to perform intersections on.

member.name: F:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Ray3DIntersectionInclude.Normal
member.summary: Include the normal objects.

member.name: F:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Ray3DIntersectionInclude.CompleteEvaluation
member.summary: If set, keep checking even if distance is greater than length.

member.name: F:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Ray3DIntersectionInclude.DisabledModels
member.summary: Include disabled models in the intersection.

member.name: T:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.SparseMatrix3Mx3ND
member.summary:
Sparse, variable-size matrix implementation containing 3x3 submatrices.
For example, a SparseMatrix3Mx3ND with M=2 (logical rows) and N=3 (logical columns) would have 6 actual rows and 9 actual columns.
This is primarily used for large system Jacobians, in which each of the rotational and translational sub-Jacobians are 3x3 matrices.
The implementation exploits sparsity for operations such as multiply, add, and equals.
The current underlying implementation is as follows: Submatrix elements are stored in an arbitrary order in a storage list, els. We keep two bookkeeping arrays of dictionaries, rowVals and colVals. Each dictionary in rowVals stores information about the submatrices in that row, specifically, the column the submatrix lives in, and its position in the storage list. For example, a submatrix A in logical row 2 and logical column 4 of the SparseMatrix, which lives in the storage list at position 5 would contribute the key value pair (4, 5) to the dictionary at rowVals[2], and the key value pair (2, 5) to the dictionary at colVals[4]. The following matrix with submatrices A, B, C and D would have this representation:
Matrix: | A 0 0 B | | 0 0 C 0 | | 0 D 0 0 |
Representation: els = [ A, B, C, D ]
rowVals = [0] -> (0, 0), (3, 1) [1] -> (2, 2) [2] -> (1, 3) colVals = [0] -> (0, 0) [1] -> (2, 3) [2] -> (1, 2) [3] -> (0, 1)

member.summary: Logical rows -- actual size is 3M

member.summary: Logical cols -- actual size is 3N

member.summary: colVals holds key value pairs [rowPosition, storagePosition], where rowPosition is the row index of the submatrix, and storagePosition is the index of the submatrix in the storage list.

member.summary: Tests the specified swept sphere against the specified intersector, deflecting and sliding it to the appropriate destination to avoid entering it.

Tests the specified swept sphere against the specified intersector, deflecting and sliding it to the appropriate destination to avoid entering it. Also populates a list of all the deflections that were performed.
Calculates the deflection of a swept sphere, returning the point of intersection and the new end-result of the broken sweep.
member.param: Set to the sphere center point at which the intersection occurs. Incoming value is ignored. This is not an out parameter so that the method doesn't have to set a value.
Incoming value should be the end of the sweep; resulting value will be the deflected destination (if intersection occurred).
List of deflections.
member.returns: False if the swept sphere didn't hit anything.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.SweptSphereDIntersectionList.RegisterSource(System.Object)
member.summary: Registers a new source which must be unregistered when done. Any subsequent adds will use the new source.
member.returns: A key that should be passed into UnregisterSource.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.SweptSphereDIntersectionList.UnregisterSource(System.Object)
member.summary: Unregisters a registered in source. Any subsequent adds will have the source of the one registered before the specified one.
member.remarks: Note that the key is only handed to the class that registered the source. If plug-ins could get at other keys, they could mess up intersections badly.
member.param: The key that was provided by RegisterSource.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.SweptSphereDIntersectionList.GetCurrentSource
member.summary: Gets the currently registered source.
member.remarks: Note that we don't hand out the key since that could be dangerous. We do, however, return the actual source.

member.name: P:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.SweptSphereDIntersectionList.CompleteEvaluation
member.summary: Gets a hint for the intersection code to say whether it should terminate early if it finds the valid result before it has tested everything. This can only be used if the entries are sorted such that it is certain that the entry is the winner. If the intersector cannot do this, the value will be ignored.

member.summary: Gets the number of intersections in this list.

member.name: P:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Vector3F.Pitch
member.summary: Gets the look-up angle of the vector
member.remarks: This handles getting the "pitch up" for a given vector. This assumes the coordinate system is Z North, X is out the Prime meridian, and Y wherever that leaves it. Pitch is defined as the angle out of the YZ plane.

member.name: P:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Vector3F.Heading
member.summary: Gets the left-right angle of the vector
member.remarks: This handles getting the "heading" for a given vector. This assumes the coordinate system is Z North, X is out the Prime meridian, and Y wherever that leaves it. Heading is defined as the angle in the YZ plane, with North being defined as 0c1

member.name: T:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Matrix4x4D
member.summary:
This represents a matrix for transforming points in 3D space. This should not be confused with the system object Drawing2D.Matrix4x4 but is more akin to DirectX's matrix, except for doubles.
. | m11 m12 m13 m14 | | m21 m22 m23 m24 | | m31 m32 m33 m34 | | m41 m42 m43 m44 | .
member.remarks: Note that spaceland uses a row vector notation akin to DirectX. In this notation when a vector has to be transformed by a matrix the row vector is POST multiplied by the matrix like this: vector * Matrix. This is opposite of the column vector notation used in most textbooks (and also OpenGL) in which a column vector is PRE multiplied by a matrix in order to transform it, like this: Matrix * vector.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Matrix4x4D.RotationX(System.Double)
member.summary: Builds a matrix that rotates around the x-axis. Uses row vector notation. In order to rotate a vector v about the X axis the vector must be POST multiplied by this matrix like this: v*M where v is the row vector and M is matrix.
member.param: Angle of rotation, in radians. Angles are measured clockwise when looking along the rotation axis toward the origin in a left handed coordinate system, and counter-clockwise in a right handed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Matrix4x4D.RotationY(System.Double)
member.summary: Builds a matrix that rotates around the y-axis. Uses row vector notation. In order to rotate a vector v about the Y axis the vector must be POST multiplied by this matrix like this: v*M where v is the row vector and M is matrix.
member.param: Angle of rotation, in radians. Angles are measured clockwise when looking along the rotation axis toward the origin in a left handed coordinate system, and counter-clockwise in a right handed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Matrix4x4D.RotationZ(System.Double)
member.summary: Builds a matrix that rotates around the z-axis. Uses row vector notation. In order to rotate a vector v about the Z axis the vector must be POST multiplied by this matrix like this: v*M where v is the row vector and M is matrix.
member.param: Angle of rotation, in radians. Angles are measured clockwise when looking along the rotation axis toward the origin in a left handed coordinate system, and counter-clockwise in a right handed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Vector3D.Pitch
member.summary: Gets the look-up angle of the vector
member.remarks: This handles getting the "pitch up" for a given vector. This assumes the coordinate system is Z North, X is out the Prime meridian, and Y wherever that leaves it. Pitch is defined as the angle out of the YZ plane.

member.name: P:Microsoft.MapPoint.Geometry.VectorMath.Vector3D.Heading
member.summary: Gets the left-right angle of the vector
member.remarks: This handles getting the "heading" for a given vector. This assumes the coordinate system is Z North, X is out the Prime meridian, and Y wherever that leaves it. Heading is defined as the angle in the YZ plane, with North being defined as 0c1
